author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Antônio Meneses, Lyrical Brazilian Cellist, Is Dead at 66
description: He began playing as a child and quickly found success for his technical command and, as one critic put it, his “thoughtful elegance.”
content: Antônio Meneses was 10 when he and his four brothers were recruited for the Rio Municipal Theater Orchestra. Their father, a French horn player in Rio de Janeiro, decided that his children should play string instruments to increase their employment odds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: In Venice, George Clooney Talks President Biden and American Politics
description: He also addressed the release plan for his new movie, “Wolfs,” co-starring Brad Pitt.
content: Midway through a Venice news conference for the crime caper “Wolfs,” one reporter told George Clooney that she would ask the question on everyone’s minds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Others Have Politicized Arlington, but Trump’s Approach Has No Precedent
description: Donald J. Trump isn’t the first candidate to run afoul of the ban on partisan activity in Arlington National Cemetery. But no one else has responded as hostilely as his campaign has.
content: Follow the latest updates on the Harris and Trump campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: 3 Moody, Terror-Laced New Thrillers
description: Our columnist on new books from T.J. Newman, Andrea Mara and A.E. Gauntlett.
content: Nobody wants to think there might be SOMEONE IN THE ATTIC (Pamela Dorman Books, 355 pp., $29). Andrea Mara’s latest book opens in Dublin as a woman named Anya finishes a bottle of wine, settles into her bath and hears an ominous rustling overhead. She doesn’t stand a chance. “Thirty seconds later, it’s over,” Mara writes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,171
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 2, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Monday Briefing: Thousands Protest in Israel
description: Plus, the Great Lego Spill of 1997.
content: Six hostages were found dead in southern Gaza over the weekend, prompting a furious reaction among Israelis who blamed the country’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, for failing to secure a deal that would have released those remaining in captivity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Colorado to Move Wolves After Animal Attacks
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 1, 2024.
content: “If a wolf wanders in and kills a cow or calf, that’s tolerable. But when they set up camp and repeatedly depredate on livestock, that’s the problem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Gabby Sobelman, Vivek Shankar and Thomas Fuller
title: Discovery of 6 Dead Hostages in Gaza Spurs Protest and Division in Israel
description: The Israeli military said Sunday that Hamas had killed the hostages before they were discovered by Israeli troops on Saturday.
content: The Israeli military said on Sunday that six bodies found in a tunnel under the Gaza Strip belonged to hostages who had been killed by Hamas, setting off a wave of grief and anger in Israel and further cleaving the deep divisions among the public, and the country’s leaders, over the future course of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Pete Wade, Guitarist on Countless Nashville Hits, Dies at 89
description: His clean tone and less-is-more approach made him a studio stalwart and a pioneer of what came to be known as the Nashville Sound.
content: Pete Wade, a prolific and versatile Nashville studio guitarist who played on scores of blockbuster hits — including Ray Price’s “Crazy Arms” and Sonny James’s “Young Love,” two of the most popular country records of the middle to late 1950s — died on Wednesday at his daughter’s home in Hendersonville, Tenn., near Nashville. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil, Gabby Sobelman and Natan Odenheimer
title: Protests Break Out Across Israel Demanding a Deal for the Release of Hostages
description: Demonstrations spread across cities around the country after the Israeli military said it had recovered the bodies of six hostages killed in Gaza.
content: Protesters flooded the streets of Israeli cities on Sunday in mass demonstrations demanding that the government immediately accept a deal for the release of hostages held in Gaza. The furious protests, some of the largest the country has seen over months of failed negotiations, came after the Israeli military announced that six of the hostages had recently been killed in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Trump Campaign Uses Statements From Gold Star Families to Attack Harris
description: It was the latest effort by the Trump campaign to defend itself after the campaign defied a ban on political campaigning at Arlington National Cemetery.
content: The partisan dispute over Arlington National Cemetery escalated on Sunday when the campaign of former President Donald J. Trump published statements from family members of slain U.S. troops attacking Vice President Kamala Harris after she criticized Mr. Trump for politicizing the cemetery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Disney+, Max, Hulu and More in September
description: “Fight Night: The Million Dollar Heist,” “A Very Royal Scandal,” a “Walking Dead” spinoff and “Agatha All Along” arrive.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of September’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: America Must Free Itself from the Tyranny of the Penny
description: Few things symbolize our national dysfunction as much as this accursed coin, which we mint by the millions because it’s too worthless to spend.
content: I was disappointed to learn, recently, that the United States has created for itself a logistical problem so stupendously stupid, one cannot help wondering if it is wise to continue to allow this nation to supervise the design of its own holiday postage stamps, let alone preside over the administration of an extensive Interstate highway system or nuclear arsenal. It’s the dumbest thing I ever heard. I have come to think of it as the Perpetual Penny Paradox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Dialysis May Prolong Life for Older Patients. But Not by Much.
description: In one recent study, the challenging regimen added 77 days of life after three years. Often, kidney disease can be managed in other ways.
content: Even before Georgia Outlaw met her new nephrologist, she had made her decision: Although her kidneys were failing, she didn’t want to begin dialysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Camille Elemia
title: China and the Philippines Trade Blame for the Latest Sea Collision
description: The United States condemned the episode near Sabina Shoal in the South China Sea and reaffirmed its defense treaty with Manila.
content: China and the Philippines traded new accusations of deliberately ramming into each other’s coast guard vessels near a disputed atoll in the South China Sea where the two countries are engaged in an escalating standoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Loneliness Epidemic Has a Cure
description: There are few higher and better callings than to forge a bond with a person and provide a place where they belong.
content: What is the most important single thing that you can do to heal our national divides and to improve the social and economic mobility of your struggling neighbors?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Happy Birthday, Dear Frozen Eggs, Happy Birthday to You
description: Egg showers have become common on social media, but a Brooklyn woman has gone a step further by throwing her eggs a birthday party every year.
content: Lauren Martinez was well prepared for a birthday party in her backyard in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She set out a tray of deviled eggs next to syringes filled with confetti; there were Eggo waffles, egg salad sandwiches, a quiche and onion dip with roe. There was also a bag of mini chocolate eggs and a tray of cupcakes, each decorated with white and yellow frosting in the shape of a fried egg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles and Marian Carrasquero
title: What Happens When Half a Million People Abandon Their City
description: About a quarter of the residents of Maracaibo, Venezuela’s second-largest city, have moved away — and more are expected to soon follow.
content: It was once a thriving metropolis in the heart of oil country in Venezuela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Tim Walz Heads Home to the Minnesota State Fair
description: The event, a must-stop for politicians through the years, has also been the site of some of the vice-presidential nominee’s most meme-able moments.
content: Shortly after Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota was tapped by Vice President Kamala Harris to be her running mate, a photo of Mr. Walz at the Minnesota State Fair in 2019 went viral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. Eugene Steuerle and Glenn Kramon
title: Young Americans Can’t Keep Funding Boomers and Beyond
description: The U.S. government spending is too heavily lavished on its older people at the expense of its young.
content: You know the expression “OK, Boomer”? Better said as “Boomer OK.” That’s because the social safety net in the United States is increasingly favoring the old over the young. And this affects our political views and the security of future generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Man Sentenced to 27 Months in Prison for Harassing Journalists
description: Tucker Cockerline was part of a group that prosecutors said vandalized the homes of a New Hampshire Public Radio reporter, her editor and her parents.
content: A New Hampshire man was sentenced to more than two years in prison for his role in the harassment and intimidation of New Hampshire Public Radio journalists whose homes were vandalized after the radio station published a story that was critical of a local businessman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Narrows at the End
description: Sala Wanetick and Emily Biegas make their New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Shbair, Erika Solomon and Hiba Yazbek
title: In Race Against Polio, Gaza Begins Vaccination Drive
description: Israel and Hamas agreed to pause the war to permit the vaccination of 640,000 children in Gaza, a daunting effort for health workers.
content: Health workers on Sunday began a polio vaccination drive in Gaza aimed at preventing an outbreak of the quick-spreading disease — a daunting challenge in a besieged enclave shattered by 10 months of war and dependent on commitments by Israel and Hamas to abide by pledged “humanitarian pauses.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Fixture of Times Past
description: A brass pendant light once hung in the lobby of the newspaper’s former headquarters.
content: If you have ever pried parents from a house in which they lived for decades, you’ll have a sense of what it was like in 2007 when The New York Times moved from 229 West 43rd Street, its home since 1913, to 620 Eighth Avenue, where it is today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: About 10,000 Hotel Workers Walk Off the Job on Labor Day Weekend
description: The union representing the workers, UNITE HERE, has planned a rolling strike for several days in cities like Boston, San Francisco and Seattle after contract negotiations stalled.
content: About 10,000 hotel workers in cities including San Francisco, Seattle and Boston walked off the job on Sunday in an attempt to disrupt Labor Day weekend travel after their union and some of the country’s biggest hotel companies failed to come to an agreement in contract negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Fund-Raiser for Jan. 6 Rioters at Trump’s Golf Club Is Postponed
description: Donald J. Trump did not plan to attend the gala event at his venue in Bedminster, N.J., but it highlighted his efforts to rewrite the history of the attack on the Capitol.
content: A gala event to raise money for some of the rioters who attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, set to take place on Thursday at former President Donald J. Trump’s golf club in New Jersey, has been postponed, according to the event website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Helicopter Crash Near Volcano in Russia’s Far East Kills at Least 17
description: The helicopter was flying tourists in Russia’s Kamchatka region. No survivors were expected among the 22 people on board, state news agencies said.
content: A helicopter flying tourists near a volcano in Russia’s Far East crashed on Saturday, killing at least 17 people, according to emergency officials who discovered the wreckage the next day and state news agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derek M. Norman
title: How Will the Nationwide Hotel Strike Affect My Labor Day Plans?
description: Though hotel chains say they’ll continue to operate normally, travelers could see disruptions as employees walked off the job in cities from Boston to Honolulu. Here’s what to know.
content: Over the busy Labor Day weekend, at least 10,000 unionized front-desk workers, housekeepers and other employees at 24 hotel properties across the country walked off the job on Sunday after failing to come to an agreement in contract negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Cass Report: Biased or Balanced?
description: Readers respond to a column criticizing a report that questioned gender-affirming care for children. Also: Child tax credit; G.O.P. plans for the economy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar and Gabby Sobelman
title: Israel’s Military Says Hostages Were Killed by Hamas Shortly Before Being Found
description: One of the victims, Hersh Goldberg-Polin, was a dual Israeli American citizen.
content: The Israeli military said on Sunday that six bodies found in Gaza were hostages who had been “brutally murdered” by Hamas, setting off a wave of nationwide grief mixed with anger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: On ‘English Teacher,’ School Is a Battlefield
description: A new FX sitcom handles the educational culture wars with a light touch.
content: The culture war often doesn’t have a physical frontline; it’s fought in op-ed columns, through social-media memes and inside people’s heads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris’s Team, With a Wink, Insists She’s an Underdog
description: Her campaign’s message that Democrats are losing, which she never voiced when President Biden was tanking the ticket, is an artful attempt to lower expectations.
content: Follow the latest updates on the Harris and Trump campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Weber
title: How America Won the Fashion War (or, at Least, the Sweatpants Battle)
description: In “Empresses of Seventh Avenue,” the fashion writer Nancy MacDonell tells the story of the New York women who created modern style.
content: “Elegance is refusal,” Coco Chanel reportedly said. Pierre Balmain reminded his customers, “Rigor, always rigor,” while Karl Lagerfeld, taking aim at the non-rigorous, specified, “Sweatpants are a sign of defeat.” For Sonia Rykiel’s part? “How can you live the high life if you do not wear the high heels?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 1, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 1, 2024.
content: An article last Sunday about the video game designer Xalavier Nelson Jr. misidentified some of the countries where Nelson has lived. They are South Korea, Italy and Germany, not France, Australia and Mexico. The article also misstated an element from the Book of Leviticus that Nelson cited as inspiration for a possible cooking game. He was referring to the text’s “goats,” not “ghosts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cody Delistraty
title: How Should We Mourn the End of Summer?
description: Sadness is a natural response to the passing of summer. We need to cope with small griefs using mechanisms similar to those we’d use for large griefs.
content: It comes gradually at first, then, like the Hemingway-ism, suddenly. Beach chairs fold up. Kayaks return to garages. Speculative camping trips remain just that. The plans and possibilities of summer cease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: East Germans Lean Toward Extremes in State Elections
description: The Alternative for Germany party was on course to win in Thuringia, according to projections, in what was seen as a worrying sign of the health of German democracy.
content: The far-right Alternative for Germany was on course on Sunday to become the strongest party in a state election for the first time, in Thuringia, and it was running a close second to mainstream conservatives in a second state, Saxony, according to projections based on early results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Ouyang
title: We Know Mental Health Affects Physical Health. Why Don’t We Act Like It?
description: Physical health and mental health are inextricably tied to each other. We need to devote the same care to both parts of ourselves.
content: “Do you think my symptoms could be from stress?” This is a question more and more of my patients have been asking me when seeking care for problems such as a stubborn cold or an aching back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das and Pragati K.B
title: Worked to the Bone, India’s Doctors Fear for Their Safety, Too
description: Grueling shifts, abuse from the public and subpar security are nothing new to medical workers in India, where a ghastly killing has put a spotlight on their plight.
content: Exhausted doctors resting in crowded on-call rooms with no locks, two to a single bed. Frustrated relatives of patients angrily challenging a physician’s diagnosis. Too few security guards to keep the peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Trump Tried to Humanize Himself. Better Luck Next Time.
description: At a Moms for Liberty event on Friday night, the former president passed up a pretty good opportunity.
content: Rolling into the Labor Day weekend, Donald Trump was able to relax a little on Friday night with a ballroom of smitten women in downtown Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A Small Town Gets an Uncomfortable Spotlight After the Boar’s Head Recall
description: A deadly listeria outbreak at the plant in Jarratt, Va., has residents worried about the town’s future.
content: Alexander Stith said the Boar’s Head deli meat plant in Jarratt, Va., is the economic heart of the small rural town. He had trouble counting the number of people he knew who work or had worked there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Second Time’s the Charm? Rematches Could Sway the Fight for Congress.
description: Candidates in both parties who lost by small margins in 2022 are trying to mount comebacks. Their races could determine which party wins control of the House.
content: Joe Kent, a far-right Republican and former Army Special Forces officer, ran for Congress two years ago as a partisan warrior. He denied that President Biden had won the 2020 election, supported rioters charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on Congress and favored banning abortions nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Hadeer Mahmoud Ahmed
title: Even Summer Nights Can’t Escape Egypt’s Economic Crisis
description: It’s so hot in Cairo that people like to go out all night. It might look like a party, but in reality, one shopkeeper said, “everybody is dead on the inside.”
content: Ten p.m. arrives in Cairo’s Sayyida Zeinab neighborhood with the same dogged tenacity as it does anywhere else, but down the fluorescent shopping streets and in the sidewalk cafes, few people used to glance at the clock. It might have been near bedtime in other countries, but Cairo was practically still waking up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Meandering? Off-Script? Trump Insists His ‘Weave’ Is Oratorical Genius.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s speeches often wander from topic to topic. He insists there is an art to stitching them all together.
content: For weeks, former President Donald J. Trump’s advisers have urged him to be more disciplined and to stop straying off-message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman
title: The Undoing of New York Nightlife’s Lawyer King
description: Sal Strazzullo made a flashy career of representing minor celebrities and those in their orbit. His own affluence was a facade.
content: Sal Strazzullo, a Brooklyn lawyer, was the legal king of New York nightlife, with a client list that extended to nightclub proprietors, disc jockeys, exotic dancers and doormen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
title: With Russia on Its Doorstep, a Ukrainian Town Packs Its Bags
description: Ukraine gambled that its move into Russia would draw Moscow’s forces away from the town of Pokrovsk. It didn’t happen. And now resigned residents are evacuating daily.
content: Placards on the train bluntly listed its purpose: “Evacuation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: Some Consider Being Biracial a ‘Predicament.’ Danzy Senna Thinks It’s Hilarious.
description: Senna, who is mixed-race, has made a career satirizing the lives of characters like her. Her new novel takes elements from her history and twists them to the extreme.
content: Long before Zendaya was our biggest young movie star, before the Kardashians became an aesthetic and economic juggernaut and certainly before Barack Obama (let alone Kamala Harris) ascended the political ranks, the novelist Danzy Senna predicted we’d soon be living through what she called the Mulatto Millennium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: Abolish the Penny?
description: Inside an intractable problem inside America’s change purses.
content: I have good news and I have bad news. Actually, I have crazy news and I have bad news. Actually, all the news I have is bad, but some of it is also crazy. Before you become totally freaked out, all the news I’m describing here is about pennies; it’s nothing life and death. But you do need to buckle up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: What to Know About the Six Hostages Killed in Gaza
description: One of the hostages, Hersh Goldberg-Polin, was an American citizen.
content: Tributes poured in on Sunday for the six hostages who were found dead in southern Gaza over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and David Guttenfelder
title: Russians Bomb Kharkiv, Ukraine Says, After Russia Reports Wave of Attacks
description: Ukraine said Russia struck the country’s second-largest city with missiles and bombs. Russian state media and local officials earlier reported that Ukraine attacked power plants and refineries with drones.
content: Russia on Sunday bombarded residential areas of Ukraine’s second largest city, Kharkiv, with ballistic missiles and powerful guided bombs, wounding more than 40 civilians, Ukrainian officials said. The attack came hours after what Russian authorities said was a wave of drone attacks against energy facilities across Russia, including an oil refinery in Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: Help! I’m ‘Older’ and on the Job Hunt.
description: Wrestling with age and a case of idea theft.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Who Are the Biggest Donors to Trump and Harris?
description: In presidential politics, campaigns are powered by billionaires. Here is a look at the most influential givers.
content: Follow the latest updates on the Harris and Trump campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas
title: How a Leading Chain of Psychiatric Hospitals Traps Patients
description: Acadia Healthcare is holding people against their will to maximize insurance payouts, a Times investigation found.
content: Acadia Healthcare is one of America’s largest chains of psychiatric hospitals. Since the pandemic exacerbated a national mental health crisis, the company’s revenue has soared. Its stock price has more than doubled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
title: 3 Israeli Police Officers Killed as West Bank Violence Spirals
description: The officers were shot and killed in what the Israeli police said was a terrorist attack. The incident followed a rise in Palestinian and Israeli violence, as Israel’s military raids Palestinian cities.
content: Gunmen killed three Israeli police officers on Sunday morning as they drove through the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the latest episode in the spiral of violence in the territory that includes attacks by Palestinian and Israeli extremists, as well as ongoing raids by the Israeli military in Palestinian cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Dragons and Sharks on a Beach Near You: The Story of the Great Lego Spill
description: Nearly five million Lego pieces plunged into the sea in 1997. The pieces are still showing up — on England’s coast, in Ireland, Belgium, France and possibly at the beach near you.
content: On a miserable, drizzly day in late June, Hayley Hardstaff, a marine biologist, took a walk along Portwrinkle Beach in Cornwall, England, and discovered a dragon. It was a Lego piece — black, plastic and missing its upper jaw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 449
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Mon, Sept. 2, 2024.
content: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level, and whether you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft and Soumya Karlamangla
title: Killing of Israeli-American Hostage Prompts Outpouring of Grief Across U.S.
description: Hersh Goldberg-Polin was among the hostages whose bodies were found on Saturday. Many remembered him as a gleeful and good-humored person — who later became a symbol of hope.
content: Hersh Goldberg-Polin loved soccer and music. He was curious, respectful and passionate about geography and travel, according to his mother. He was born in the Bay Area and moved to Israel when he was 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: This May Just Be the Absolute Best Tuna Melt
description: Golden Diner’s tuna melt is a study in texture, in contrasting flavors, in griddled perfection.
content: Good morning. What’s better than the Sunday of a three-day weekend? If you’re lucky, you’ve already been off work for a day. And if you’re going to be off tomorrow, too? That can feel like a gift, a room in your house you didn’t know you had. Luxuriate in it if you can. There may be back-to-schoolish responsibilities looming. But today’s just for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Simon Verity, World-Renowned Stone Carver, Is Dead at 79
description: He headed the team that created the statues of biblical figures at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.
content: Simon Verity, a British stone carver whose bevy of works included the statues that adorn the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Upper Manhattan as well as grottoes, tombstones, fountains and floor inscriptions, like the brass lettering that marks the shrine to Thomas Becket at Canterbury Cathedral in England, died on Aug. 11 at his home in Llandeilo, Wales. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘His Expression Suggested He Was Trying to Solve a Puzzle’
description: A brisk April day in Manhattan, an overdue introduction on the F and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: What to Watch for in East German State Elections on Sunday
description: The prospect of a strong performance by the far-right Alternative for Germany party in two state elections is only one of the problems for Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
content: On Sunday, voters in the eastern German states of Saxony and Thuringia go to the polls in elections that are being carefully watched in Berlin and across Europe, in part because the far-right Alternative for Germany party is poised to do well in one or both elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper and Axel Boada
title: Polio Vaccination Campaign Begins in Gaza
description: In an effort to prevent a polio outbreak, health workers in Gaza began a vaccination drive against the quick-spreading disease. The effort depends on Israel and Hamas abiding by their pledged “humanitarian pauses.”
content: In an effort to prevent a polio outbreak, health workers in Gaza began a vaccination drive against the quick-spreading disease. The effort depends on Israel and Hamas abiding by their pledged “humanitarian pauses.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Thousands Protest in Tel Aviv After 6 Hostages Are Killed in Gaza
description: After the recovery of six hostages that the Israeli military said had been killed by Hamas, demonstrators filled the streets of Tel Aviv demanding that the government do more to bring the remaining hostages home.
content: After the recovery of six hostages that the Israeli military said had been killed by Hamas, demonstrators filled the streets of Tel Aviv demanding that the government do more to bring the remaining hostages home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Protesters in Jerusalem Demand an Immediate Hostage Deal
description: Israelis demonstrated outside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office after the military recovered the bodies of six killed hostages from a tunnel underneath Rafah, Gaza.
content: Israelis demonstrated outside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office after the military recovered the bodies of six killed hostages from a tunnel underneath Rafah, Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times
